title: 113_s1974
content: The Act may be cited as the "Learning Opportunities Created At Local Level Act" or the "LOCAL Level Act". It includes findings and the sense of Congress. Congress finds that Section 9527 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 prohibits the Federal Government from controlling a State's curriculum or allocation of resources. Section 9529 also prohibits the Federal Government from funding various educational activities. The Secretary of Education has created waivers and grants to influence State educational agencies to implement national school standards and assessments. The Race to the Top Fund incentivized states to adopt the Common Core State Standards. The Race to the Top assessment grants awarded to PARCC and SMARTER Balance led to the development of assessments aligned with the Common Core State Standards, influencing K-12 curriculum. States were coerced into accepting the standards through waivers imposed by the Secretary of Education. States were pressured into adopting Common Core State Standards and related assessments. Congress believes that states and local educational agencies should have the authority to determine their own educational curricula and assessments. States are sovereign entities that deserve respect and should resist federal interference in education. SEC. 9527 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to prohibit federal mandates, direction, or control over educational curricula and assessments. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to prohibit federal officers or employees from mandating or incentivizing specific instructional content, academic standards, assessments, curriculum, or programs of instruction in State, local educational agencies, or schools. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 prohibits federal officers from mandating specific instructional content, academic standards, assessments, curriculum, or programs of instruction in State, local educational agencies, or schools. This includes not requiring any spending of funds or incurring costs not covered by the Act, and not conditioning financial support on the adoption of specific educational standards or programs. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 prohibits federal officers from mandating specific instructional content, academic standards, assessments, curriculum, or programs of instruction in State, local educational agencies, or schools. This Act also prohibits the endorsement of any curriculum using funds provided to the Department. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 prohibits federal officers from mandating specific instructional content, academic standards, assessments, curriculum, or programs of instruction in State, local educational agencies, or schools. It also prohibits the Department from endorsing, approving, developing, requiring, or sanctioning any curriculum using funds provided under this Act. Additionally, no State shall be required to have academic standards approved or certified by the Federal Government to receive assistance under this Act. The Act does not mandate national school building standards for State, local educational agencies, or schools. SEC. 4. PROHIBITION ON FEDERALLY SPONSORED TESTING AND TESTING MATERIALS. Section 9529 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to prohibit federally sponsored testing and testing materials. The Act prohibits the use of funds for developing, testing, or distributing federally sponsored national tests or testing materials aligned with Common Core State Standards, except for international comparative assessments authorized by law. The Education Sciences Reform Act of 2002 prohibits the use of funds for developing national tests aligned with Common Core State Standards, except for international comparative assessments authorized by law. The tests are administered to a representative sample of pupils in the United States and foreign nations. SEC. 5 prohibits the use of funds from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 for any assessments aligned with Common Core State Standards.
